div.p: Most illustrious man, when I had already sealed the letters, I received some news from Italy, namely that Cardinal Crescentius Leguleus has been declared the legate of the future council, just as I had predicted in my letter to the King of England.

Other cardinals will not preside with him, but two bishops, one of whom will be from Fano (as I suppose). In Rome, there is a great scarcity of grain. Cardinal Cornaro of Venice, a notably wicked man, has died. But listen to other things that torment me and will also torment you, I am sure: a most pestilent heresy has arisen in Padua, which not only suggests that men should be rebaptized, but that Christ was born from the corruptible seed of Joseph; and to support this horrendous blasphemy, they deny a large part of the Gospels, oh shame! The matter is certain.
I am expecting new brothers any day now, who are preparing to flee, but they are of sincere doctrine, not those fanatical and impious men.
There are many other things that you will gladly hear, but I prefer to bring them with me rather than commit them to letters, especially since I do not have a reliable messenger.

There is a good and wealthy man among us who wishes to buy the Old and New Testament in German, well-bound in folio. If Mr. Michael would send it to Mr. Comander, who would take care of it for me, I will bring him the money. Farewell in the Lord and pray for all the churches, which are so disturbed by this foul tempest.
I greet the church and the whole school.
Vicosoprano, on the Ides of March 1551.
To the most illustrious man Mr. Heinrich Bullinger, etc.
